A perceptual hash is similar to an image thumbnail=E2=80=94but instead of p=
roducing
a smaller image, the result is a hash code. Unlike conventional ha=
shing, a
perceptual hash conflates information such that very similar image=
s will
produce identical hash codes (the opposite of avalanching). This is =
very
important when using image-based states for novelty; we want agents to=

visit states that are interestingly new (e.g. "a car just entered my field=

of view"), not trivially different (e.g. "a single pixel changed from 127
=
to 129"). A perceptual hash is more likely to ignore trivial differences
si=
nce it conflates image noise. Deep Curiosity Search accomplishes a
similar =
goal by rewarding agents for visiting substantially different
regions of th=
e game world; but it would be interesting to see how a
perceptual hash migh=
t work with DeepCS.

In any case, the linked technique encourages across-tr=
aining novelty:
rewarding agents for visiting states that have never been s=
een before in
the entire history of training. In other words, once a state =
has been
visited, it is never "interesting" again for the rest of training.=


Our work instead promotes intra-life novelty: rewarding agents for visiti=
ng
new states within their lifetime, regardless of whether those states hav=
e
been visited in prior episodes of training history. All states become
"in=
teresting" again at the start of each lifetime (in Atari, at the start
of e=
ach new game).

--000000000000bc83d10570077b62
Content-Type: text/html; charset="UTF-8"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

<div dir=3D"ltr"><div><div>A perceptual hash is similar to an image thumbna=
il=E2=80=94but instead of producing a smaller image, the result is a hash c=
ode. Unlike conventional hashing, a perceptual hash conflates information s=
uch that very similar images will produce identical hash codes (the opposit=
e of avalanching). This is very important when using image-based states for=
 novelty; we want agents to visit states that are interestingly new (e.g. &=
quot;a car just entered my field of view"), not trivially different (e=
.g. "a single pixel changed from 127 to 129"). A perceptual hash =
is more likely to ignore trivial differences since it conflates image noise=
. Deep Curiosity Search accomplishes a similar goal by rewarding agents for=
 visiting substantially different regions of the game world; but it would b=
e interesting to see how a perceptual hash might work with DeepCS.<br><br><=
/div>In any case, the linked technique encourages across-training novelty: =
rewarding agents for visiting states that have never been seen before in th=
e entire history of training. In other words, once a state has been visited=
, it is never "interesting" again for the rest of training.<br><b=
r></div>Our work instead promotes intra-life novelty: rewarding agents for =
visiting new states within their lifetime, regardless of whether those stat=
es have been visited in prior episodes of training history. All states beco=
me "interesting" again at the start of each lifetime (in Atari, a=
t the start of each new game).<br></div>

--000000000000bc83d10570077b62--
